X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=29390171; y=8vrdZXWaOxafVxL7AjUo2RAY7QrGChKRPRzJvYVB3wm6Jr1bIhACYTjGoQ4

Ken, Joel, unfortunately I am not convinced of the merits of your
suggested method,

Problem 1, larger dimensionality problems,
I must agree with Jeffs early assessment, the novelty fitness function
(NFF) is exceedingly well suited to solving these mazes. That appears to
be a strength, but to my mind only because the the dimensionality of the
maze is severely limited. If the search was to be conducted in a 8
dimensional maze instead, NFF would fill up it's "previous novel solution"
repository real fast but still be getting nowhere.

Ken, you state that since the agent has a limited amount of time to live,
searching of dead area will end quickly since evolution will only search
for a limited time in any one direction. This is true, except that if
there are one more dimension, the area (volume actually) to search is
radically increased. And if there are two more dimensions, the area
(what's the name for m^4?) positively explodes. Thus even searching
relatively close to the starting position will result in vast amounts of
tests. And without any indication which route is better, searching of this
hypercube (in the 4 dimension example) would go on for a very long time.
Any tangent would be equally viable, no matter whether they be actually
better or not.

I'm not saying a regular fitness function would perform better, it would
fail miserably just as well. This simply isn't a problem that evolution is
well adapted to solving - if there is no series of small incremental steps
that bring you measurably (measured via fitness) closer to the goal, then
you're toast. Small reversals in fitness can be handled by none-elitist
methods (speciation etc), but not large ones.

Problem 2, closing doorways that cannot be opened;
I'd guess that the one time out of 40 that the NFF failed, it started
early to investigate a deep alley in the maze that brought it very close
to the actual goal, but then the population shifted away from that alley
and investigated another part of the maze instead. At that point, that
particular alley is blocked for further investigation - there's a big gulf
of no fitness improvements to traverse that's simply so deep that nothing
can make it across (evolve across) without being killed off due to the
fact that that part of the novelty space had already been investigated
(partially, but that's unknowable to the NFF). 

To explain it in a simpler scenario. Say you have two corridors, one
leading left for 8 units and one leading right for 16 units, where the
goal actually is. Evolution starts going right (actually towards the goal,
but that's invisible to the MFF) and it reaches 10 units, when it randomly
discovers a nice area to the left to investigate. All resources are
shifted to the left area but that way lies a dead end. At that point, when
the dead end is reached, evolution is stuck with the fact that there is
absolutely NO fitness gradient to climb at all, because further evolution
to the left is penalized because the area has been exhaustively searched,
and to the right, there's a great gulf of also searched area, beyond which
the goal lies.

The larger the maze and the more of these limiting doorways there are, the
greater the chance that one of them will be blocked off by prematurely
shifting focus.

Sorry to be such a downer, raining on your parade and all that. There
might be situations where this method works wonders, but to be a panacea,
further thinking is, to my mind, required.

with regards,
mattias
